note_models.name: NLP Comprehensive

fields: What is few-shot learning in NLP?

Goal: Learn new tasks with only few examples
Methods: In-context learning (GPT), meta-learning, prompt engineering
Example: Show GPT-3 three examples, it performs new classification
Advantage: Reduces need for large labeled datasets

Definition: Crafting input text to elicit desired behavior from language models
Examples: "Translate to French:", "The sentiment of this text is"
Techniques: Zero-shot, few-shot, chain-of-thought prompting
Importance: Critical for getting good performance from large LMs
What is domain adaptation in NLP?

Problem: Models trained on one domain perform poorly on another
Solutions: Fine-tuning, domain adversarial training, gradual unfreezing
Example: News model applied to social media text
Challenge: Limited labeled data in target domain
What are the main ethical concerns in NLP?

Bias: Models reflect training data biases (gender, race, religion)
Privacy: Models may memorize sensitive training information
Misuse: Deepfakes, propaganda, surveillance applications
Fairness: Equal performance across demographic groups
What is multilingual NLP and what are the main approaches?

Goal: Build models that work across multiple languages
Approaches: Multilingual embeddings, cross-lingual transfer, zero-shot
Models: mBERT, XLM-R, multilingual T5
Challenges: Low-resource languages, script differences, cultural context
What is explainable AI in NLP?

Goal: Understand how models make decisions
Methods: Attention visualization, gradient-based attribution, probing
Challenges: Attention weights don't always indicate importance
Applications: Debugging, trust, regulatory compliance
What is continual learning in NLP?

Goal: Learn new tasks without forgetting previous ones
Problem: Catastrophic forgetting when fine-tuning on new data
Solutions: Elastic Weight Consolidation, rehearsal, progressive networks
Application: Updating models with new domains/languages
What is knowledge distillation in NLP?

Goal: Transfer knowledge from large teacher to small student model
Method: Train student to match teacher's output distributions
Benefits: Smaller, faster models with similar performance
Applications: Model compression, edge deployment, efficiency
